Award.AbstractNarration:
Based on the number of extant species, insects are arguably the most successful group of animals on earth and the ability to fly is central to their eminence. Although past research has made great progress in understanding the basic aerodynamic mechanisms employed by insects, we know much less about how these animals control the motion of their flapping wings, which is the basis of their remarkable agility. Insects such as flies are endowed with only a dozen or so tiny muscles at the base of the wing with which to control wing motion. This research project will use a combination of genetic and optical techniques to directly observe how insects use their muscles to adjust the flapping pattern of their wings. The investigations will help uncover one of the greatest mysteries about these extraordinarily successful creatures and provide insight for the design and fabrication of miniature mechanical devices such as insect-sized flying robots. In addition, the outreach and training effort of the project will include support of undergraduate research during the academic year.

This proposal will focus on fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster), which are capable of rapid aerial maneuvers and are amenable to many genetic approaches for recording and manipulating muscles and motor neurons. In particular, by expressing the genetically-encoded, optical calcium sensor GCaMP, the investigators will directly observe the activity of the entire steering muscle system while animals perform visually-elicited flight maneuvers. The functional role of muscles used for different maneuvers will be investigated with high spatial and temporal resolution by combining electrophysiology with high speed videography. The project will also explicitly test the role of specific muscles using optogenetic reagents to activate motor neurons in intact animals. Collectively, these approaches will determine how insects perform flight maneuvers using such a limited set of muscles and expand our knowledge of the general principles of motor control employed by a group of earth's most successful creatures. Results from the studies will be disseminated through publication in peer-reviewed journals and through presentations at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Judged by sheer number of species, insects represent the most successful group of animals in the history of life, and the key to their ecological dominance is the ability to fly. Insects were the first animals that evolved active flight, which is an efficient form of locomotion that allows animals to search for food and other resources over large spatial scales. Flight is, however, a challenging behavior that requires many specializations in body morphology (such as wings), neurobiology (such as fast, high resolution eyes), and physiology (such as powerful muscles). The work in this proposal focused on the highly specialized flight muscles of insects that enable the animals to rapidly steer and maneuver. The key finding is that the flight control muscles of insects are organized into two distinct functional classes, one set (called tonic muscles) that are continuously adjusted to regulate the baseline pattern of wing motion, and another set (called phasic muscles), that the insect recruits only occasionally when it needs to execute a rapid maneuver. Through the coordinated action of these two muscles groups, the insects are able to achieve their remarkable aerial agility.

All animals face the daunting task of controlling locomotion using their limb muscles, but the problem is particularly challenging for flies and other small insects that steer using only a small set of 12 muscles that insert on the base of the wing. Unlike many locomotor systems ? a human leg, for example - the morphological and biomechanical complexity of the wing hinge makes it difficult to infer the functional role of the steering muscles based only on their origins and insertions. To understand how insects can execute precise flight maneuvers using such a small set of muscles, we developed a novel imaging technique that made use of genetic tools available in the model species, Drosophila melanogaster ? the common fruit fly. First, we created transgenic flies who expressed a protein that changed fluorescence whenever the steering muscles became active during flight. We then developed a microscope system and analysis software that allowed us to image the activity of all the wing control muscles in intact flies, as they flew within a computer-controlled flight simulator. Using this new approach, it was possible to simultaneously records from all the steering muscles of a fly, and thus determine the means by which it controls the motion of its wings.

The experiments uncovered a remarkably efficient system by which the insects control wing motion. The twelve muscle at the base of each wing are organized into four anatomical groups, with each group attaching to one of four tiny skeletal elements at the base of the wing called sclerites. When the muscles pull on the sclerites, the wing motion is distorted in a way that changes the aerodynamic forces and torques that are generated. By pulling on different combinations of sclerites, the fly is able to execute the full range of maneuvers that are required to fly, much like a pilot steers by adjusting the stick and pedals of an aircraft. The central finding of this project is that the fly uses two different types of muscles to control the forces exerted on the four sclerites and thus the actions of the wings. Each sclerite is equipped with one continuously active ?tonic? muscle, and one or more occasionally active ?phasic? muscles. By adjusting the activity of the small tonic muscles, the fly can adjust that baseline pattern of wing motion, effectively trimming the system to achieve straight, stable flight. When it needs to execute a quick rapid maneuver ? for example when avoiding a predator ? the fly actives one or more of the larger phasic muscles, which rapidly distort the pattern of wing motion to quickly adjust the forces and torques. Thus, by segregating the function of its control muscles into two groups, the fly can achieve both continuous stability as well as rapid maneuverability. The results help explain how a small array of muscles can achieve fine motor control and provide a substantive foundation for understanding the function of arguably the most complicated mechanical joint found in nature. The findings offer insight into the adaptations that led to the extraordinary radiation of insects and provide design principles for the engineering of small autonomous vehicles.
